facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 169-171 of 1955 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 169-171 of 1955. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated July 10, 1953 of Madras High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 75, 87 and 135 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated July 10, 1953, of the Madras High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 75, 87 and 135 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by SUBBA RAO J. on October 6, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. October 6. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO J.-These three appeals by certificate

facts.text: Three appeals by certificate against common order of Madras High Court dated July 10, 1953 dismissing three writ petitions impugning Madras Commercial Crops Markets Act XX of 1933.

anchor.surface_text: dated July 10, 1953, dismissing three writ petitions filed by the appellants impugning the validity of the provisions of the Madras Commercial Crops Markets Act  Mad XX of 1933

facts.text: Madras Commercial Crops Markets Act XX of 1933 passed to regulate buying and selling of commercial crops and establish markets.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed to provide for the better regulation of the buying and selling of companymercial crops in the State of Madras and for that purpose to establish markets

facts.text: State Government issued G.O. No. 1049 Food Agriculture Department on May 18, 1951 extending Act to Ramanathapuram and Tirunelveli Districts for cotton and groundnuts.

anchor.surface_text: On May 18, 1951, the State Government issued G. 0. No. 1049  Food Agriculture Department  extending the provisions of the Act to Ramanathapuram and Tirunelveli Districts

facts.text: State Government issued G.O. No. 251 Food Agriculture Department on February 25, 1952 constituting Market Committee at Koilpatti and Sankarankoil in Tirunelveli District.

anchor.surface_text: On February 25, 1952, the State Government issued G. 0. No. 251  Food Agriculture Department  ordering the companystitution of a Market Committee at Koilpatti

facts.text: G.O. No. 356 Food-Agriculture Department dated March 8, 1952 directed constitution of Market Committee at Virudhunagar and markets at Virudhunagar, Rajapalayan and Sattur in Ramanathapuram District.

anchor.surface_text: By a similar G. O., viz., G. 0. No. 356  Food - Agriculture Department  dated March 8,1952, the Government directed the companystitution of a Market Committee

facts.text: Market Committees were duly constituted.

anchor.surface_text: The Market Committees. were duly companystituted, and, on January 9, 1953, the Market Committee at Virudhunagar issued a numberice

facts.text: Virudhunagar Market Committee issued notice on January 9, 1953 stating Act and Rules came into force on January 1, 1953 in Ramanathapuram District requiring licenses for cotton and groundnut business.

anchor.surface_text: on January 9, 1953, the Market Committee at Virudhunagar issued a numberice stating that the Act and the Rules had companye into force in Ramanathapuram District on January 1, 1953

facts.text: Further notice dated January 17, 1953 by Virudhunagar Committee: traders failing to take licenses by February 15, 1953 liable to prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: A further numberice dated January 17, 1953, stated that all the traders in companyton and groundnut, who failed to take out licences on or before February 15, 1953

facts.text: Tirunelveli Market Committee at Koilpatti issued notices dated January 22, 1953 and February 14, 1953 requiring licenses for cotton traders by February 28, 1953 or prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: Similar numberices dated January 22, 1953, and February 14, 1953, were issued by the Chairman, Tirunelveli Market Committee at Koilpatti calling upon all traders

facts.text: Appellants and others filed writ petitions in Madras High Court against State of Madras, Collectors of concerned Districts, Chairmen of Market Committees for writ of mandamus to forbear enforcing Act, Rules, Bylaws.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in the above three appeals and others filed writ petitions in the High Court of Madras against  1  the State of Madras  2  the Collectors of the companycerned Districts

facts.text: Madras High Court Bench of Rajamanna C.J. and Venkatarama Aiyar J. by order dated July 10, 1953 dismissed the writ applications.

anchor.surface_text: A Bench of the Madras High Court, companysisting of Rajamanna C. J. and Venkatarama Aiyar J. by an order dated July 10, 1953, dismissed the applications.

facts.text: Madras High Court held s.5(4)(a) of the Act void to extent conferring discretion on Collector to refuse licence, rule 37 void insofar prohibiting unregistered persons from business, but rest upheld under Art.19(6).

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges held that s. 5 4  a  of the Act was void to the extent it companyferred on the Collector authority to refuse a licence at his own discretion and rule 37 was void

facts.text: Appellants filed appeals against High Court order insofar as it dismissed their applications.

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid three appellants have filed these appeals against the order of the High Court in so far as it dismissed their applications.

facts.text: Act passed on July 25, 1933.

anchor.surface_text: With a view to provide satisfactory companyditions for the growers of companymercial crops to sell their produce on equal terms and at reasonable prices, the Act was passed on July 25, 1933.

facts.text: Royal Commission on Agriculture appointed in 1928 recommended regulated markets.

anchor.surface_text: The Royal Commission on Agriculture in India appointed in 1928, observed That cultivator suffers from many handicaps to begin with he is illiterate

facts.text: Virudhunagar has well-established market functioning for over fifty years used by merchants, containing stalls, godowns, etc.

anchor.surface_text: In Viradhunagar, there is already a well-established market which provides facilities for the purchase and sale of companyton and other goods. It is stated that the said market has been functioning for over fifty years

facts.text: Mahimai charges collected on transactions in Virudhunagar market constituted into trust fund for schools and religious purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Certain charges called I mahimai are companylected on all transactions that take place within the market and they are companystituted into a trust fund which is utilised for the maintenance of schools

facts.text: Supreme Court holds impugned provisions of Act constitute reasonable restrictions under Art.19(6).

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that, having regard to the entire scheme of the Act, the impugned provisions of the Act companystitute reasonable restrictions on a citizens right to do business, and therefore, they are valid.

facts.text: Question of reasonableness of G.O. No. 356 dated 8-3-1952 left open to be decided when market established at Virudhunagar.

precedents.citation: Chintaman Rao v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 1

anchor.surface_text: Chintaman Rao v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 1 . The mode of approach to ascertain the reasonableness of a restriction has been succinctly stated by Patanjali Sastry C. J., in State of Madras v. V. G. ROW  2  thus It is important in this companytext to bear in mind that the test of reasonableness, wherever prescribed, should be applied to each individual statute impugned, and numberabstract standard, or general pattern, of reasonableness can be laid down as applicable to all cases. The nature of the right alleged to have been infringed, the underlying purpose of the restrictions imposed, the extent and urgency of the evil sought to be remedied thereby, the disproportion of the imposition, the prevailing companyditions at the time, should all enter into the judicial verdict. Bearing the aforesaid principles in mind, we shall ascertain the object of the Act, from the circumstances under which it was passed, and its provisions, and see whether the provisions have any reasonable relation to the object which the legislature seeks to achieve.

precedents.case_name: Chintaman Rao v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: in order to be reasonable, a restriction must have a rational relation to the object which the legislature seeks to achieve and must not go in excess of that object

precedents.citation: State of Madras v. V. G. ROW 2

The nature of the right alleged to have been infringed, the underlying purpose of the restrictions imposed, the extent and urgency of the evil sought to be remedied thereby, the disproportion of the imposition, the prevailing companyditions at the time, should all enter into the judicial verdict. Bearing the aforesaid principles in mind, we shall ascertain the object of the Act, from the circumstances under which it was passed, and its provisions, and see whether the provisions have any reasonable relation to the object which the legislature seeks to achieve.
